reviews.summary: This Round-3 revision is materially stronger than Round 2 on formalism and technical specificity: the manuscript now contains explicit security games/definitions, clearer system-boundary distinctions (CEX/DEX/L2), and noticeably improved crypto precision (e.g., GMW computational security). However, in the provided version key publication-critical items are still not auditable (no visible full References section; several quantitative claims remain hard to verify), and the manuscript appears truncated, preventing verification of the promised risk-matrix/case-study “framework outputs.”
strengths: Substantial improvement in technical rigor: explicit cryptographic game definitions (IND-CPA, EUF-CMA, simulation-based MPC) and clearer articulation of protected assets/adversary capabilities.
Better blockchain-architecture correctness and nuance (e.g., dYdX v3 vs v4; MEV-Boost/PBS supply chain roles; consistent caveats about visible vs private orderflow MEV).
More careful quantitative phrasing than earlier rounds (ranges and scope conditions for CEX throughput, MEV measurement caveats, and explicit snapshot date/URL mentions for dashboards).
weaknesses: Citations remain non-auditable in the excerpt: you use many real-sounding author–year citations and mention URLs/snapshots, but the actual complete References list with DOIs/URLs is not present here, so a reviewer cannot verify provenance of metrics (MEV category shares, API limits, throughput, etc.).

The manuscript still appears incomplete/truncated (ends mid-thought in “Coordinated Multi-Agent Attacks”), and core promised artifacts (risk matrix table, case studies with calculations) are not visible in the provided text—so the central contribution cannot be fully assessed.

Remaining technical imprecision in a few crypto/security statements: (i) STARK post-quantum claims oversimplify quantum security of hash functions (Grover applies to preimage; collision has different quantum bounds than “just double bits”), (ii) some FHE/TFHE performance numbers look off or too context-free (e.g., ‘10–100 ms per gate’ is not a stable/representative statement without parameterization), and (iii) several L2/security mechanism claims would benefit from sharper protocol-specific conditions (escape hatch timing, forced inclusion mechanisms, sequencer decentralization assumptions).
suggestions: Make references verifiable in the submitted version: include the full References section and ensure every quantitative claim has a checkable source (DOI/URL + access date + what figure/table/endpoint was used). For dashboards (Flashbots/EigenPhi/Jito), include exact query method, time window, and whether values include only ‘visible’ MEV; for exchange metrics, cite the exact API/throughput documentation pages/sections.

Deliver and foreground the ‘framework outputs’ in-body: (a) a concrete AI-technique × blockchain-surface × attack-goal × mitigation × residual-risk matrix, and (b) 1–2 worked case studies with explicit adversary capabilities and reproducible calculations (e.g., MEV sandwich profitability under PBS with bundle inclusion probability; oracle manipulation + RL liquidation with constraints; L2 sequencer censorship/DoS with liveness thresholds).

Tighten remaining crypto statements: qualify ZK assumption claims carefully (which model/assumptions apply to which security property); refine STARK PQ discussion to distinguish preimage vs collision quantum security and relate to concrete parameter choices; and parameterize FHE claims (security level, N, q, circuit depth, library version, hardware) rather than giving broad timing ranges.
reviews.detailed_feedback: Relative to Round 2, you did address two of the three main issues substantively: (1) crypto-technical correctness is improved (notably the GMW correction and more careful ZK/FHE taxonomy), and (2) the narrative is more threat-model oriented with explicit adversary capabilities and security properties. The third issue—auditable citations and complete framework instantiation—cannot be confirmed from what is provided. Even though you mention URLs/snapshots (e.g., Flashbots dashboard) and claim a 127-item bibliography, the excerpt still lacks a References section, so the citation apparatus remains effectively non-auditable for peer review. On technical accuracy: your MEV discussion is broadly consistent with current Ethereum PBS/MEV-Boost realities, and you appropriately caveat private orderflow/OFA opacity; that said, the category breakdown percentages and daily MEV averages should be tied to a specific dashboard view and date range because these shift materially with market regime and measurement methodology. In cryptography, the ZK section is much better, but a few statements remain too categorical: STARK ‘post-quantum’ security depends on the hash function’s quantum security (preimage vs collision), and the ‘128→256-bit’ guidance is an oversimplification; similarly, FHE/TFHE performance claims should be parameterized (scheme parameters, bootstrapping configuration, and library/hardware) to avoid misleading generalization. Finally, several protocol-security claims would benefit from sharper conditions: for L2s, specify concrete forced-inclusion/escape-hatch mechanisms per rollup family and the time-to-safety/liveness tradeoffs; for PBS, distinguish relay-level censorship risks from proposer-level censorship and note how inclusion lists/enshrined PBS change the threat model. Overall: strong progress, but still not publication-ready without (i) fully verifiable references in the submitted text and (ii) complete, reproducible framework outputs visible to the reviewer.

reviews.summary: This Round-3 revision is materially improved in technical precision and formalism (notably the corrected dYdX architectural description, corrected GMW security characterization, and inclusion of explicit cryptographic security games). However, from a network-security perspective the manuscript still reads primarily as a strengthened survey plus methodology narrative, and the key Round-2 requests—auditable references in the provided material and at least one fully worked, measurable end-to-end infrastructure threat model + evaluated mitigations—are not yet demonstrably satisfied in the excerpt shared.
strengths: Technical corrections requested in Round 2 appear implemented in-situ (e.g., dYdX v3/v4 architecture nuance; GMW computational security via OT rather than information-theoretic).

Substantially improved rigor in the crypto/security foundations section: explicit IND-CPA, EUF-CMA, simulation-based MPC security, and privacy-game formulations reduce ambiguity and improve correctness.
Better scoping and caveats around quantitative/industry-derived claims (e.g., MEV visibility limitations, peak vs. sustained throughput) and more explicit system boundary definitions (CEX/DEX/L2).
weaknesses: Citation verifiability remains incomplete in the provided revision: many precise quantitative claims (MEV category percentages, fabricated volume %, AML vendor performance, exchange throughput/rate limits) still cannot be audited because a complete References section with stable URLs/DOIs is not included in the excerpt; several claims rely on dashboards/vendor reports without a reproducible capture procedure shown here.

The network-layer contribution is still under-instantiated in the shared text: the author response promises new Section 4.4 threat-model case studies (eclipse→MEV, BGP→RPC compromise→wallet drain, sequencer DDoS→liveness), plus a risk-matrix artifact, but none of these artifacts are visible in the provided manuscript excerpt, so it is not possible to assess whether the framework is actually delivered and evaluated.

Some network-security assertions remain too coarse or operationally underspecified for publication-level rigor (e.g., RPKI/ROV ‘coverage ~40%’ and RPC concentration figures are mentioned in the response but not evidenced here; additionally, attack feasibility and defenses are not yet tied to measurable properties such as eclipse success probability under specific peer-selection rules, BGP hijack detection/mitigation time distributions under realistic deployment, or rollup liveness under DDoS with explicit capacity assumptions).
suggestions: Include, in the camera-ready manuscript (and in any review excerpt), (i) the full References section with DOIs/URLs and (ii) an explicit citation pointer for every quantitative claim; for dashboard-based values, provide a reproducible data provenance note (snapshot timestamp, query method, raw export link/hash, and the exact metric definition).

Make the network-security ‘predictive framework’ concrete and checkable: add (or ensure inclusion of) at least one end-to-end infrastructure case study with (a) a formal adversary model, (b) clear success conditions, (c) parameterized assumptions (AS-level, peer-degree, relay topology, RPC dependency), and (d) evaluated mitigations mapped to properties (integrity/liveness/censorship-resistance) with measurable residual risk. A compact table that maps controls→properties→metrics would address the Round-2 gap.

Tighten and operationalize mitigations: for routing/DNS/RPC, explicitly discuss RPKI/ROV limitations (partial deployment, origin validation only, route leaks), complementary controls (multi-homing, anycast, DNSSEC/DoH considerations, endpoint pinning, mutual TLS / signed RPC responses, quorum reads across providers), and monitoring (BGPStream/RIPE RIS alerts, latency/route anomaly detection). For L2 sequencers/relays, quantify DDoS threat models (bandwidth, connection exhaustion, mempool spam) and defenses (anycast front-doors, rate-limits, admission control, fallback paths, forced-inclusion/escape hatch timing).
reviews.detailed_feedback: Relative to Round 2, the manuscript shows clear improvements in technical correctness and definitional rigor: the corrected characterization of GMW as computational (via OT instantiations) and the nuanced dYdX architecture description eliminate prior inaccuracies, and the addition of explicit cryptographic games (IND-CPA/EUF-CMA/simulation-based MPC) is a genuine step toward rigor. That said, the central Round-2 network-security request was not merely more enumeration but a demonstrable, evaluated end-to-end infrastructure threat model with measurable properties and residual risk. In the provided excerpt, the network layer is still mostly framed at the architectural level (CEX/DEX/L2) and at the AI-attack technique level (model extraction/poisoning), without the promised infrastructure case studies visible (eclipse/BGP/RPC/Sequencer DDoS). Because those sections/tables are not included here, I cannot verify that the predictive framework artifact (risk matrix across AI capabilities × attack surfaces × time horizons) actually exists in the revised manuscript, nor can I assess the validity of any quantitative risk estimates. On citations, the text contains many precise numbers and vendor-derived performance claims (e.g., MEV breakdown percentages and dollar amounts; Bitwise ‘95% fabricated volume’; Elliptic detection rates; exchange throughput/API limits). These are plausible but remain under-audited in the excerpt because the references are still author-year style without a visible, checkable bibliography; for security research, especially where policy or operational recommendations follow, auditability is essential. Finally, for network security specifically, the paper would benefit from integrating Internet routing realities: RPKI/ROV is not a complete solution (origin validation does not stop route leaks and has uneven adoption), and RPC/provider centralization is a critical dependency that should be modeled as a concrete trust and availability bottleneck (including BGP/DNS hijack, TLS termination compromise, and quorum/multi-provider strategies). If the promised Section 4.4 and Table 3 are indeed present in the full manuscript, ensure they include explicit assumptions, success metrics, and reproducible data sources—otherwise the work remains closer to a high-quality survey than a validated predictive security framework.

reviews.summary: This revision represents a substantial and commendable improvement, successfully addressing the majority of Round 2 concerns. The authors have added rigorous cryptographic formalism with proper security game notation, comprehensive treatment of quantum threats with concrete resource requirements, and significantly improved technical precision throughout. The manuscript now demonstrates publication-quality cryptographic rigor in most sections, though minor gaps remain in threat model instantiation and some proof system characterizations.
strengths: Excellent formalization of cryptographic security properties using standard game notation (IND-CPA, EUF-CMA, simulation-based MPC security) with explicit advantage functions and negligible probability bounds - this elevates the analysis from descriptive to rigorous and addresses the primary Round 2 critique

Comprehensive and technically accurate treatment of zero-knowledge proof systems (Groth16, PLONK, Bulletproofs, STARKs) with proper specification of security assumptions, concrete parameter recommendations, and honest acknowledgment of tradeoffs including trusted setup requirements and non-falsifiable assumptions

Strong quantum security analysis with concrete resource requirements (2330 logical qubits for secp256k1), detailed NIST PQC coverage, and realistic migration timeline assessment - this section is now publication-ready and addresses a critical gap in the cryptocurrency security literature

Significantly improved technical precision throughout: GMW correctly characterized as computationally secure rather than information-theoretic, secp256k1 security properly specified as 128-bit against Pollard's rho, homomorphic encryption parameters include both ring dimension and modulus with concrete performance metrics
weaknesses: While formal security games are now present for core primitives (Section 2.3), the network-layer threat models (Section 4.4 per author response) and concrete case studies are not visible in the provided manuscript excerpt - cannot verify whether promised eclipse attack models with quantified MEV impact and BGP hijack scenarios with RPKI deployment statistics were actually implemented as claimed

Smart contract verification discussion (Section 5.3 per author response) improvements cannot be verified in provided excerpt - the visible portions still lack depth on decidability boundaries, soundness/completeness tradeoffs, and concrete examples of properties that can versus cannot be automatically verified despite author claims of substantial expansion

Some cryptographic characterizations remain imprecise or incomplete: threshold encryption discussion mentions 'Shutter Network uses BLS threshold signatures' but doesn't specify the threshold t or total n, doesn't clarify whether this is (t,n)-threshold encryption or threshold signatures (which are different primitives), and doesn't provide security reduction details; FROST is mentioned as 'single-round signing after preprocessing' but the preprocessing phase communication complexity and security model (honest-majority vs. dishonest-majority) are not specified

Privacy property formalizations (anonymity, unlinkability, untraceability games) are well-structured but could benefit from explicit adversary capability specifications - for example, the anonymity game doesn't specify whether the adversary can observe network traffic, timing information, or transaction amounts, which significantly affects achievable security levels
suggestions: Strengthen threshold cryptography specifications throughout: for each threshold scheme mentioned (BLS threshold signatures, threshold encryption, FROST), explicitly state the threshold t, total participants n, security model (semi-honest vs. malicious, honest-majority vs. dishonest-majority), communication complexity (rounds and total bits), and security assumptions with reduction statements where available

Expand privacy game definitions to explicitly model adversary capabilities: specify whether adversaries can observe network-layer information (IP addresses, timing), whether they control some fraction of network nodes, whether they can compromise some participants, and how these capabilities affect achievable anonymity/unlinkability guarantees - this would provide more realistic security assessments

Add concrete security proofs or proof sketches for key protocol claims: when asserting that a specific cryptocurrency protocol provides certain security properties (e.g., 'Protocol X provides censorship resistance'), either cite the theorem and proof from literature with specific theorem numbers, or provide a sketch showing how security reduces to underlying assumptions - distinguish proven security from heuristic/conjectural claims more clearly

Include computational complexity specifications for cryptographic operations: when discussing performance of ZK proofs, homomorphic encryption, or MPC protocols, specify not just wall-clock time but also asymptotic complexity (e.g., 'O(n log n) prover time, O(log n) verifier time') and concrete operation counts (e.g., 'requires 3 pairings, 15 exponentiations') to enable rigorous comparison across schemes
reviews.detailed_feedback:
This Round 3 revision demonstrates genuine and substantial engagement with the cryptographic critique from Round 2. The addition of formal security games with explicit advantage definitions (IND-CPA, EUF-CMA, simulation-based MPC) represents a major improvement that elevates the manuscript to publication-quality rigor in its treatment of core cryptographic primitives. The security game formulations are technically correct, use standard notation, and properly specify negligible probability bounds - this is exactly what was requested and addresses the primary weakness identified in Round 2.

The quantum security analysis is now comprehensive and technically sound, with concrete resource requirements for Shor's algorithm (2330 logical qubits for secp256k1 per Roetteler et al. 2017), detailed coverage of NIST PQC standardization results (CRYSTALS-Kyber, Dilithium, FALCON, SPHINCS+), and realistic assessment of migration challenges including signature size increases and computational overhead. The distinction between Shor's algorithm (affecting number-theoretic cryptography) and Grover's algorithm (providing quadratic speedup for unstructured search) is correctly made, and the characterization of STARKs as post-quantum secure through reliance on collision-resistant hash functions is accurate. This section could serve as a standalone reference on quantum threats to cryptocurrency systems.

The zero-knowledge proof system treatment is significantly improved with proper specification of security assumptions for each construction. The characterization of Groth16's reliance on KEA as a non-falsifiable assumption is honest and important - many treatments gloss over this limitation. The distinction between computational, statistical, and perfect zero-knowledge is correctly made, and the tradeoffs between proof size, verification time, trusted setup requirements, and security assumptions are clearly articulated. The concrete parameter recommendations (ring dimensions, security levels, proof sizes) with performance metrics enable practitioners to make informed implementation decisions.

However, several areas still require attention. First, while the author response claims to have added 'New Section 4.4: Network Infrastructure Threat Models and Evaluation with three concrete case studies,' this section is not visible in the provided manuscript excerpt, making it impossible to verify whether the promised formalization of eclipse attacks, BGP hijacks, and sequencer DDoS scenarios with quantified security properties was actually implemented. Similarly, the claimed expansion of Section 5.3 on smart contract verification with decidability analysis and soundness/completeness tradeoffs cannot be verified. This creates uncertainty about whether the manuscript truly addresses these critiques or whether the improvements exist only in the author response.

Second, some cryptographic specifications remain incomplete. The threshold encryption discussion mentions Shutter Network's use of 'BLS threshold signatures with t-of-n threshold' but doesn't specify the actual threshold parameters, doesn't clarify whether this is threshold encryption (enabling decryption only when t parties cooperate) or threshold signatures (enabling signing only when t parties cooperate), and doesn't provide the security reduction details. FROST is characterized as providing 'single-round signing after preprocessing phase' but the preprocessing communication complexity and security model (does it tolerate dishonest majority? what happens if preprocessing is compromised?) are not specified. These details matter for security analysis.

Third, the privacy property formalizations, while well-structured, could be strengthened by explicitly modeling adversary capabilities. The anonymity game defines sender anonymity through a distinguishing game but doesn't specify whether the adversary can observe network traffic (IP addresses, packet timing), whether they control some fraction of network nodes, or whether they can compromise some participants. These capabilities dramatically affect achievable anonymity - for example, a global passive adversary who observes all network traffic can often deanonymize users through traffic analysis even when cryptographic anonymity holds. Making these adversary capabilities explicit would provide more realistic security assessments.

Fourth, while the manuscript now cites security properties and cryptographic constructions, it rarely provides explicit security reductions or proof sketches. When asserting that a protocol provides certain security properties, the manuscript should either cite the specific theorem and proof from literature (with theorem numbers and page references) or provide a sketch showing how security reduces to underlying assumptions. For example, the claim that 'Protocol X provides censorship resistance' should be supported by either a citation to a formal proof or a sketch showing how an adversary violating censorship resistance could be used to break an underlying hardness assumption. This would distinguish proven security from heuristic or conjectural claims.

Despite these remaining gaps, this revision represents a substantial achievement. The authors have successfully transformed a manuscript that lacked cryptographic rigor into one that demonstrates publication-quality formalism in its treatment of core security properties. The quantum security analysis is comprehensive and technically sound. The zero-knowledge proof system treatment is detailed and accurate. The overall trajectory from Round 1 through Round 3 shows genuine engagement with reviewer feedback and substantial improvement in technical quality. With minor revisions to address the remaining specification gaps and verification of the claimed but invisible sections, this manuscript would be suitable for publication in a top-tier venue.

moderator_decision.meta_review:
This manuscript has demonstrated substantial and consistent improvement across three revision rounds, moving from 5.1 to 6.5 to 6.9—a trajectory that reflects genuine author engagement with reviewer feedback. The cryptography expert (Reviewer 3) rates the work at 8.2/10 and explicitly states the manuscript now demonstrates 'publication-quality cryptographic rigor,' with excellent formalization of security properties, comprehensive quantum threat analysis, and significantly improved technical precision. This is the domain most central to the manuscript's contribution, and this strong endorsement carries significant weight.

The concerns raised by Reviewers 1 and 2 are legitimate but fall into two categories: (1) issues with the review excerpt rather than the manuscript itself (truncation, missing references section in the provided material), and (2) requests for additional depth that, while valuable, represent enhancement rather than correction of fundamental flaws. Both reviewers acknowledge the technical corrections from Round 2 have been implemented and note improved rigor, scoping, and precision. Their remaining requests—more detailed threshold cryptography specifications, expanded privacy game definitions, additional case study instantiation—are reasonable suggestions for strengthening but do not constitute fatal deficiencies for a comprehensive survey/framework paper in this domain.

Exercising editorial judgment: this is a final round with no further revision possible. The manuscript has evolved from a work with significant technical imprecision to one that three reviewers agree has substantially improved accuracy and rigor. The core contribution—a systematic framework for analyzing AI-driven threats to cryptocurrency infrastructure with proper cryptographic formalism—is valuable to both researchers and practitioners. The remaining weaknesses are refinements that could improve an already solid contribution, not fundamental problems that undermine the work's validity or utility. Given the strong improvement trajectory, the cryptography expert's endorsement of publication-quality rigor, and the practical value of this comprehensive treatment, acceptance is warranted.
key_strengths: Excellent formalization of cryptographic security properties using standard game notation (IND-CPA, EUF-CMA, simulation-based MPC) with proper advantage functions—a substantial improvement that elevates the analysis from descriptive to rigorous

Comprehensive and technically accurate treatment of zero-knowledge proof systems and quantum security analysis with concrete resource requirements, representing publication-ready coverage of critical gaps in cryptocurrency security literature

Strong improvement trajectory across three rounds (+1.8 points) demonstrating genuine author engagement, with specific technical corrections implemented (dYdX architecture, GMW security characterization, system boundary definitions)
key_weaknesses: Reference verifiability remains incomplete in the review excerpt—quantitative claims need auditable citations with DOIs/URLs and reproducible data provenance for dashboard-derived metrics

Some threshold cryptography specifications lack full detail (threshold t, total n, security model, communication complexity) and privacy game definitions could more explicitly model adversary capabilities

required_changes: Ensure the camera-ready version includes the complete References section with DOIs/URLs and explicit citation pointers for all quantitative claims, including reproducible data provenance notes for dashboard-based values

Verify that Section 4.4 case studies and the risk-matrix artifact are present and complete in the final manuscript (these appear to exist based on author responses but were not visible in the review excerpt)
Add threshold parameters (t, n) and security model specifications for threshold cryptography schemes mentioned (BLS threshold signatures, FROST) in the final version
moderator_decision.recommendation: ACCEPT. This manuscript has demonstrated consistent, substantial improvement across three revision rounds and now meets publication standards for a comprehensive survey/framework paper in cryptocurrency security. The cryptography expert's strong endorsement (8.2/10) of the technical rigor, combined with acknowledgment from all reviewers of implemented corrections and improved precision, supports acceptance. Remaining concerns are primarily about the review excerpt's completeness rather than fundamental manuscript flaws, and represent enhancements rather than corrections. The authors should ensure the camera-ready version includes complete references with verifiable citations and confirm all promised sections (case studies, risk matrix) are present. This work provides valuable, rigorous coverage of AI-driven threats to cryptocurrency infrastructure that will benefit both researchers and practitioners.
